p: Ae. aegypti was the dominant species, accounting for 51.6% of this fauna (Table 1). It was followed in descending order, among the potential vectors of ZIKV, by Ae. vittatus (19.4%), Ae. bromeliae (8.4%), Ae. unilineatus (8.3%), Ae. hirsutus (3.8%), Ae. luteocephalus (1.4%), Ae. taylori (0.9%), Ae. fowleri (0.6%), Ae. furcifer (0.3%) and Ae. dalzieli (0.1%). The dominant species varied according to the breeding site and land cover (Table 1). Thus, Ae. aegypti was the dominant species in tree holes from forests (52.9%) and villages (74.5%), rock holes from forests (43.3%) and barrens (65.7%), tires from forests (97.1%) and discarded containers from villages (54.5%). This species was the only one present in tires from villages. The relative abundance of Ae. aegypti in different tree holes from all land cover were significantly different ( p < 0.001).
